Award.AwardTitle: Transforming STEM Career Pathways: Examining a Multigenerational Mentorship Environment to Support Persistence of Women of Color Pursuing STEM Education at Community Colleges
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by increasing the success of women of color (Black/African American, Latina, Asian American, and Indigenous women) who are pursuing STEM education at two-year institutions. Women remain significantly underrepresented in many STEM fields and in the educational pathways that lead into those fields. This situation has been attributed to gender-based experiences that result in feelings of invisibility and isolation. Such experiences tend to be exacerbated for women who hold other marginalized identities, such as social class, citizenship, age, and race. Yet, most efforts designed to broaden STEM participation try to advance student persistence by targeting singular marginalized identities. Researchers have cited the importance of developing a dual race- and gender-based social network to increase student success. The importance of an intersectional approach is even greater because of the COVID-19 pandemic’s impacts on women of color. In addition to managing their own education in an online format, many women of color have major responsibilities in maintaining their families' health and survival during the pandemic. These efforts often require managing food, financial, and housing insecurity while navigating complex, disjointed support systems. Advancing STEM participation of women of color requires the creation of spaces that holistically support the complex interplay of their intersecting identities. In these “counterspaces,” women of color can develop asset-based narratives and the mindset and skills needed to thrive academically and psychologically. This project will examine the effectiveness of a culturally responsive counterspace that features multigenerational mentorship and is focused on wellbeing and thriving. It is expected that this counterspace will promote the persistence of women of color in their pursuit of STEM education.

The project will evaluate the effectiveness of a program designed to address the psychological and emotional challenges that women of color experience in pursuing STEM careers. Project goals include include applying the model of counterspaces and multigenerational mentoring to women of color in community college and understanding the ways in which an explicit focus on STEM identity development and psychosocial wellbeing may affect STEM persistence among women of color at community colleges. To achieve these goals, the project team will conduct a multi-methodological research study and a program evaluation comprised of both process and outcome evaluation components. This study will add to the understanding of counterspaces, including the specific features of counterspaces that support STEM identity development of women of color at community colleges. The study expects to identify the ways in which activities that employ multigenerational mentorship can promote feelings of belonging, emergent STEM identities, and STEM persistence of women of color at the community college. The research will expand understanding of the factors that inform the decision-making processes of Black/African American, Latina, Asian American, and Indigenous women in community colleges who complete a two-year program and enter the STEM workforce or transfer into a four-year STEM program, or do not persist in STEM. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of this work was to advance STEM persistence among women who identify as Black, Latinx, Indigenous/Native American, Asian, or Bi/Multiracial at two-year institutions. In service of this goal, the current project was designed to examine the effectiveness of the I CAN PERSIST STEM Initiative, a culturally sustaining mentoring program designed to support the retention and advancement of Women of Color in STEM in a manner centered on thriving. This specific project, titled ''Transforming STEM Career Pathways: Examining a Multigenerational Mentorship Environment to Support Persistence of Women of Color Pursuing STEM Education at Community Colleges'' (NSF grant # 2044354) was funded for two years (2021-2022 and 2022-2023), along with a no-cost-extension year (2023-2024).


The I CAN PERSIST STEM Initiative employs a robust five-tiered multigenerational mentoring framework to promote STEM persistence. Key to this framework is drawing on the collectivist cultural values that is at the heart of many Communities of Color in order to support women and girls across five educational levels: high school, community college, undergraduate, graduate, and STEM professionals. Here, Women and Girls of Color, who are interested in or currently pursuing STEM majors/careers, are immersed in an affirming shared-identity community where they have the opportunity to mentor and be mentored by an oasis of diverse and talented Women and Girls of Color at different educational and life stages. In doing so, we counteract the belief that ''you can't be what you don't see''.


Despite encountering a myriad of challenges related to recruitment and COVID-19, we successfully recruited one cohort of 15 community college STEM Scholars from Boston, Massachusetts. These students were enrolled in academic majors such as computer science, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, physics, and biology. They described being drawn to the I CAN PERSIST STEM Initiative because of experiences with being one of the only women and/or Women of Color in their classrooms, feeling uncertain if STEM was a good fit because of the stark underrepresentation of people like them in STEM, wanting to mentor the next generation of Women of Color in STEM, feeling a lack of support in their current STEM environments, and wanting support from those who share similar life experiences.


Throughout their yearlong participation in the I CAN PERSIST STEM Initiative, community college STEM Scholars received near peer mentorship from other scholars pursuing their associate degrees. One STEM Scholar shared the following about how near-peer mentorship impacted her STEM persistence, ''I feel like I'm not doing this alone and this alleviates the anxiety I have about whether I'm cut out to be a software engineer.'' Community college STEM Scholars also received mentorship from undergraduate and graduate Women of Color enrolled in STEM majors at the University of Massachusetts at Boston as well as from Women of Color STEM professionals who worked in industry, academia, or non-profit agencies. With regards to the latter mentorship experience, one STEM scholar shared, ''Seeing so many strong and engaged Black and Brown women in STEM across the U.S. makes me feel like a tribe exists for me, and this makes me want to persist in my studies.'' STEM Scholars also had the opportunity to mentor high school Youth of Color from across the Boston metropolitan area as part of the annual STEM Day held at UMass Boston.


While the immersive, multigenerational, mentorship experience was consistently and overwhelming regarded as integral to their STEM persistence, community college STEM Scholars also described difficulty balancing the competing demands of full time/part time work, academics, caregiving responsibilities for children, siblings, and/or aging family members, as well as financial hardships. Despite their interest, the combination of these challenges impacted STEM Scholars' engagement in the Initiative's activities.


Results from this project highlight the significance of an intersectional, multi-generational, mentorship program for promoting STEM persistence among Women of Color in STEM at two-year colleges. It also highlighted the necessity of more robust wrap-around supports including family care programs, comprehensive fellowship packages, and flexible modalities for engaging with mentoring opportunities. Taken together, this project highlights the importance of intentionally integrating an intersectional focus in STEM retention and workforce development programs. It is not enough to just focus on ''women and minorities,'' because such efforts will fall short of uniquely meeting the needs of Women of Color in STEM.
